comments.author: @dr.ravishankarpolisetty2820
comments.text:
Extremely bad idea!

The idea of using YouTube videos and AI tools like ChatGPT to replace traditional lectures in tertiary education may seem convenient and cost-effective, but it misses a crucial aspect of learning‚Äîthe *human connection* between teacher and student. Education is not merely about delivering information; it is about the *exchange of energy**, **passion**, and **intent* that happens in real-time during a lecture. A recorded video may convey facts, but it cannot replicate the spontaneity, emotion, and personalized guidance that a teacher offers in the moment. The *aura* of the teacher‚Äîtheir tone, body language, and enthusiasm for the subject‚Äîplays a significant role in making complex ideas more understandable and memorable. The way in which a teacher adjusts their explanation based on the immediate feedback from students or engages them through lively discussions creates a dynamic learning environment that goes far beyond passive consumption of content.

Furthermore, while AI tools like ChatGPT can be incredibly helpful for answering questions or providing supplemental information, they cannot replace the *mentorship* and *personal touch* a teacher brings to the classroom. Teachers inspire, motivate, and challenge students to think critically, question assumptions, and explore new perspectives. These human interactions foster intellectual growth and emotional resilience in students‚Äîskills that are essential in life, not just in academics. The role of a teacher is not only to impart knowledge but also to **shape character**, nurture curiosity, and instill confidence in students. Thus, reducing education to recorded videos and automated responses undermines the rich, transformative experience that a true teacher-student relationship offers.
